In iraq Mosul based on the impact on other hot climates what’s the possible energy savings of sealing cracks in windows and doors 
Vs perlite and sealant (they call it labakh) for the walls inside
Vs perlite and sealant for walls outside 
Vs perlite and sealant for walls inside and outside  
Vs replacing windows with two pane glass 
Vs replacing windows with two pane glass with a plastic buffer between the metal part of the window that goes outside and the window that goes inside 
Vs painting the roof with a special sealant and white reflective paint a few mm thick 

I’m wanting to work out for my insulation training what might be the best place to intervene in terms of cost/benefit

If you can do some calculations for how much energy actually costs in iraq today between the government and the generators and what each intervention is likely to cost for an average 150sqm house in Mosul iraq 

You can also recommend other options for our table and help me come up with a sales engineering design for our training with the intro day being  informational second part being application (hands dirty, design doing things) and the last part is business and customer related figuring out material costs return on investment for the customer how to talk to them to help them see the benefits helping study their home and needs and what might work best with their best needs and constraints in mind 

Is there anything about ventilation that can fit into our model that we can install as a retrofit that might help us too?

**In Mosul’s hot-dry climate, the cheapest kWh is the one you never have to generate.  For a typical 150 m² single-family house that uses ~10 000 kWh of electricity a year (6 000 kWh for cooling), the numbers below show that low-cost air-sealing delivers the quickest pay-back (≈ 2–3 yrs), while cool-roof paint and perlite plasters make sense where the owner buys a lot of expensive generator power.  Double-glazing gives similar energy savings but will only pay for itself if fuel subsidies are removed or if comfort, acoustics and dust-control have a high non-energy value to the client.  Adding solar- or wind-driven ventilation on the roof can further cut attic temperatures by 5-10 °C and trim another 5-8 % off cooling bills.**

---

## 1.  Mosul energy-cost backdrop  

| Source of electricity | Typical household price | Notes |
|---|---|---|
| National grid (subsidised) | **IQD 19.4 / kWh ≈ US ¢1.5** citeturn0search0 | Flat tariff; supply limited to ~12 h day in summer. |
| New tiered tariff (KRG example) | **US ¢5.8 – 14.1 / kWh** for higher blocks citeturn1search0 | Gives a sense of where Iraq may move as subsidies ease. |
| Neighbourhood diesel generator (“ampere line”) | **IQD 20 000 – 35 000 per A month → ≈ US ¢9.5–13 / kWh** (24 h service) citeturn5search0 | Most Mosul families buy 10–20 A in summer. |

A family of four to five typically consumes **3 700–16 000 kWh yr-¹** depending on appliance ownership and blackout hours citeturn6search2turn6search3.  In the table that follows we model the mid-range **10 000 kWh yr-¹**, 60 % of which is space-cooling.

---

## 2.  Envelope measures: energy- and cash-savings snapshot  

| # | Retrofit measure (single action) | Cooling-energy cut | Cap-ex (Mosul market, labour+material) | Annual bill saving* | Simple pay-back |
|---|---|---|---|---|---|
| 1 | **Seal cracks around windows & doors** (weather-strip + silicone) | **≈ 15 %** citeturn12search0 | **≈ US $200** | **US $75** | **2 – 3 yrs** |
| 2 | **Perlite–lime plaster on interior walls** (“labakh”) | **≈ 15 %** (20–40 % reported vs plain plaster) citeturn14search9turn14search1 | **≈ $900** (150 m² × $6 m-²) | **$75** | **12 yrs** |
| 3 | **Perlite plaster on exterior only** | **≈ 20 %** citeturn14search9 | **≈ $1 200** | **$100** | **10 yrs** |
| 4 | **Perlite inside + outside** | **≈ 25 %** | **≈ $2 100** | **$125** | **15 yrs** |
| 5 | **Replace single windows with 6-12-6 mm double-glazing (uPVC frame)** | **≈ 20 %** citeturn11search1 | **≈ $2 800** (40 m² × $70 m-²) citeturn18search0 | **$100** | **24 yrs** |
| 6 | **As #5 but with thermal break (plastic spacer & interrupted frame)** | **≈ 25 %** (extra 3–5 %) citeturn11search2 | **≈ $4 000** | **$125** | **28 yrs** |
| 7 | **White reflective roof coating (2–3 mm elastomeric + sealer)** | **≈ 15 %**; peak demand cut 11–27 % citeturn13view0 | **≈ $750** (150 m² × $5 m-²) | **$75** | **9 – 10 yrs** |

\*Annual bill saving assumes a blended tariff of US ¢9.6 / kWh (40 % grid, 60 % generator).  When the owner relies only on the grid (¢1.5 / kWh) pay-backs lengthen 6-fold; when the home is 100 % generator (¢13 / kWh) they shorten to ~2 / 3 of the values shown, so always walk the client through *their* mix.  

---

## 3.  What this means for your sales-engineering pitch  

### Quick wins to put first in any bundle  
1. **Air-sealing + door sweeps** – cheapest, DIY-friendly, immediate comfort gain.  
2. **Cool-roof coating** – a strong visual “before/after” for trainees and customers; pairs well with solar attic fans.  

### “Step-change” packages for generator-heavy users  
* **Exterior perlite plaster** or **double-glazing** become attractive when the owner is already spending > $100 month on diesel fees or when subsidies shrink.  
* Offer staged financing: perlite now, glazing next year.  

### Talking points for the customer  
* Show the *cash flow*: IQD 1 = ≈ US $0.00076.  Turning a $75 annual saving into local currency (≈ IQD 99 000) lands better.  
* Emphasise **non-energy benefits**: less dust ingress, quieter interiors, mould-free walls, longer‐lasting paint.  
* For rental units, quote the future resale premium (e.g., recent Mosul listings advertise “double glass” 5-10 % above comparable stock).  

---

## 4.  Adding low-cost ventilation retrofits  

| Device | Cooling benefit | Typical cost | Fit-with-insulation |
|---|---|---|---|
| **Solar-powered attic or roof-ridge fan** | Lowers attic air by 5–10 °C; 5–8 % HVAC cut citeturn20search1turn20search3 | US $250–400 kit | Complements cool-roof paint & perlite ceiling slab. |
| **“Wind-catcher” or whirly-bird ventilators** | Passive stack + wind draw; good in breezy summer evenings | US $40 each | Requires airtight ceiling to avoid negative pressure in living space. |
| **Through-wall energy-recovery ventilator (mini-ERV)** | Supplies fresh air with ≤ 10 % cooling penalty | US $500/unit | Pair with aggressive air-sealing to maintain IAQ. |

---

## 5.  Three-day training layout for Mosul workshop  

### **Day 1 – Foundations & Diagnostics**  
* **Morning**: Climate data, Iraq tariff trends, generator economics.  
* **Afternoon**: Blower-door demo (or incense & pressure pans), infrared camera walk-through, basic psychrometrics.  

### **Day 2 – Hands-dirty Application**  
* Mix and spray a **perlite labakh** panel; measure R-value with heat-flux plates.  
* Install weather-strips and a sample **uPVC double sash**; teach shim-in-frame technique.  
* Roll-apply **cool-roof coating** on a mock roof deck; surface-temp logging in the sun.  
* Mount a **solar attic fan**; students wire the PV module and set thermostat.  

### **Day 3 – Business & Customer Success**  
* Excel/Google-Sheet **ROI calculator** (inputs above pre-filled).  
* Role-play: homeowner objections (“But the grid kWh is only 20 dinars!”).  
* Sourcing session: local perlite suppliers, aluminium fabricators, sealant wholesalers.  
* Group project: design a bundle for a 120 m² rental flat vs a 300 m² villa; present pay-back, comfort and resale upsides.  

Provide each participant with:  

1. **Audit checklist** (leak points, wall build-ups, roof colour, meter photos).  
2. **Unit-cost card** in IQD & USD.  
3. **Customer one-pager** explaining why 1 A of generator power costs ~ USD $26 month and how a 15 % drop in kWh knocks off almost 4 A of subscription.  

---

## 6.  Extra options to add to the comparison table  

* **Shade structures / pergolas on west façade** – cheap steel & reed mat.  
* **Radiant barrier under roof sheeting** – pairs well with attic fan.  
* **Programmable thermostat + ceiling-fan upgrade** – behavioural savings.  
* **Solar PV + battery** – large cap-ex but hedges against diesel inflation; include as “Day-3 stretch topic”.  

---

### Key sources (selected)  

- Subsidised grid tariff – GlobalPetrolPrices (2024 data) citeturn0search0  
- Tiered pricing trend – 964 Media report on KRG tariffs citeturn1search0  
- Generator ampere fees – TheMediaLine (May 2025) citeturn5search0  
- Household load studies – Science Publishing Group (3 712 kWh/yr) & ResearchGate load model (15 951 kWh/yr) citeturn6search2turn6search3  
- Air-sealing 10–20 % energy cut – US EPA “Seal & Insulate” citeturn12search0  
- Weather-stripping ≤ 1 yr pay-back – US DOE Energy Saver citeturn12search1  
- Perlite plaster 20–40 % benefit – MDPI study & Perlite Institute tech sheet citeturn14search9turn14search1  
- Double-glazing 18–28 % cooling reduction – ScienceDirect insulation-code paper citeturn11search1  
- Cool-roof 11–27 % peak-load cut – US EPA Heat-Island guidance citeturn13view0  
- Attic-fan impact – Solar Guys & FSEC performance paper citeturn20search1turn20search3  
- Local window cost US $45–70 m-² – Alibaba exporters to Iraq citeturn18search0  

Feel free to plug these figures into your own calculator and adapt the pitches to a client’s real tariff mix.  That way the training stays grounded in the numbers that matter for Mosul’s families today.

I don’t know how many people use these wind catchers or are they being removed? Are they retrofit able? Available in the market? How does the fan in the upper floor (there is no attic in Mosul) help?

Can you help me talk as a sales engineering design for someone in iraq who talks in amperes not kwhs and who’s problem is upstairs is unlivable in the summer during the afternoon and can you explain the expense, the install process, the lifestyle and quality improvements (air quality / heat / etc) - the difference possible in oC rather than % energy (we use that to make the calculations) and then help me as a business person think what might be the best business in terms of cost of material cost of sale likelihood the person will be convinced and market size for the intervention - let’s do the sales engineering part and business development or new businesses in Mosul that need to convince a reluctant audience here’s some more detailed information : # Energy Efficiency Solutions for Mosul Residential Buildings

Roof treatments offer the fastest payback (3-7 years) for cooling energy savings in Mosul's extreme heat, where private generators cost $0.142/kWh [![Electricity sector in Iraq - Wikipedia](claude-citation:/icon.png?validation=1AB8DB31-3343-45DE-9FD3-E81B23553762&%3D)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electricity_sector_in_Iraq) and grid electricity is available only 6-8 hours daily. [![Foreign Policy](claude-citation:/icon.png?validation=1AB8DB31-3343-45DE-9FD3-E81B23553762&%3D)](claude-citation:/icon.png?validation=1AB8DB31-3343-45DE-9FD3-E81B23553762&%3D) A comprehensive thermal management approach combining traditional Iraqi building methods with modern insulation can reduce cooling costs by 25-35% annually. The $233 billion Iraqi reconstruction market presents significant opportunities for contractors trained in both energy efficiency retrofits and culturally-appropriate sales approaches. [![Atlantic Council](claude-citation:/icon.png?validation=1AB8DB31-3343-45DE-9FD3-E81B23553762&)](claude-citation:/icon.png?validation=1AB8DB31-3343-45DE-9FD3-E81B23553762&)

## Energy landscape shapes intervention priorities

Iraq's residential electricity crisis creates unique market conditions for energy efficiency investments. [![Climate change in Iraq - Wikipedia](claude-citation:/icon.png?validation=1AB8DB31-3343-45DE-9FD3-E81B23553762&%3D)](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Climate_change_in_Iraq) [![Climate profile: Iraq - Atlantic Council](claude-citation:/icon.png?validation=1AB8DB31-3343-45DE-9FD3-E81B23553762&%3D%3D)](https://www.atlanticcouncil.org/programs/middle-east-programs/rafik-hariri-center-for-the-middle-east/empowerme/macromena/climate-profile-iraq/) Government-subsidized electricity costs only $0.015/kWh [![Electricity sector in Iraq - Wikipedia](claude-citation:/icon.png?validation=1AB8DB31-3343-45DE-9FD3-E81B23553762&%3D)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electricity_sector_in_Iraq) but remains unavailable for 16-18 hours daily during Mosul's brutal summers, forcing households to rely on neighborhood diesel generators charging $0.142/kWh— [![Electricity sector in Iraq - Wikipedia](claude-citation:/icon.png?validation=1AB8DB31-3343-45DE-9FD3-E81B23553762&%3D)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electricity_sector_in_Iraq)nearly 10 times the subsidized rate. [![Wikipedia](claude-citation:/icon.png?validation=1AB8DB31-3343-45DE-9FD3-E81B23553762&%3D)](claude-citation:/icon.png?validation=1AB8DB31-3343-45DE-9FD3-E81B23553762&%3D) With peak temperatures exceeding 50°C [![Siemens-energy](claude-citation:/icon.png?validation=1AB8DB31-3343-45DE-9FD3-E81B23553762&%3D)](claude-citation:/icon.png?validation=1AB8DB31-3343-45DE-9FD3-E81B23553762&%3D) and 2,289 annual cooling degree days, [![Yearly & Monthly weather - Mosul, Iraq](claude-citation:/icon.png?validation=1AB8DB31-3343-45DE-9FD3-E81B23553762&%3D%3D)](https://www.weather-atlas.com/en/iraq/mosul-climate) [![Iraq - Desert, Arid, Hot | Britannica](claude-citation:/icon.png?validation=1AB8DB31-3343-45DE-9FD3-E81B23553762&%3D)](https://www.britannica.com/place/Iraq/Climate) the average 150m² home consumes 2,500-3,500 kWh annually for cooling alone, [![Experimental investigation of phase change materials for insulation of residential buildings - ScienceDirect](claude-citation:/icon.png?validation=1AB8DB31-3343-45DE-9FD3-E81B23553762&%3D)](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S2210670717304341) [![A global model of hourly space heating and cooling demand at multiple spatial scales | Nature Energy](claude-citation:/icon.png?validation=1AB8DB31-3343-45DE-9FD3-E81B23553762&%3D)](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41560-023-01341-5) translating to $350-500 in generator costs. [![Climate profile: Iraq - Atlantic Council](claude-citation:/icon.png?validation=1AB8DB31-3343-45DE-9FD3-E81B23553762&)](https://www.atlanticcouncil.org/programs/middle-east-programs/rafik-hariri-center-for-the-middle-east/empowerme/macromena/climate-profile-iraq/)

This reliability-cost paradox fundamentally alters traditional energy efficiency calculations. While subsidized grid electricity would extend payback periods indefinitely, generator dependency makes even modest efficiency improvements financially attractive. The 48 GW summer peak demand against only 25-26 GW available capacity [![Iraq Grapples With Mammoth Summer Peak Load | MEES](claude-citation:/icon.png?validation=1AB8DB31-3343-45DE-9FD3-E81B23553762&%3D%3D)](https://www.mees.com/2024/6/28/refining-petrochemicals/iraq-grapples-with-mammoth-summer-peak-load/7cd623a0-354e-11ef-8388-734184aca7a9) ensures this generator reliance will continue despite government promises and international investments. [![Electricity sector in Iraq - Wikipedia](claude-citation:/icon.png?validation=1AB8DB31-3343-45DE-9FD3-E81B23553762&%3D%3D)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electricity_sector_in_Iraq)

## White roof coatings deliver immediate returns

Among seven analyzed thermal interventions, reflective roof treatments emerge as the clear winner for Iraqi conditions. At $1,600-2,560 total cost for a 150m² house, high-performance cool roof coatings with Solar Reflectance Index values above 100 reduce roof surface temperatures by 15-20°C. [![Heat Reflective Paint, Cool Roof Coating, Summer cool Paint - Coolroof ®](claude-citation:/icon.png?validation=1AB8DB31-3343-45DE-9FD3-E81B23553762&%3D%3D)](https://www.coolroofpaint.com/) This translates to 20-31% cooling load reduction, saving $350-550 annually with a payback period of just 3-7 years. [![Cool Roof Paint Price 2025: Starts From Rs1099](claude-citation:/icon.png?validation=1AB8DB31-3343-45DE-9FD3-E81B23553762&%3D%3D)](https://www.nobroker.in/blog/cool-paint-price/)

The intervention's appeal extends beyond economics. Installation requires only 2-3 days with minimal disruption, using locally available materials from suppliers like Ezukam. [![(PDF) Comparative Study of Building Envelope Cooling Loads in Al-Amarah City, Iraq](claude-citation:/icon.png?validation=1AB8DB31-3343-45DE-9FD3-E81B23553762&%3D%3D)](https://www.researchgate.net/publication/336956480_Comparative_Study_of_Building_Envelope_Cooling_Loads_in_Al-Amarah_City_Iraq) The 10-15 year service life provides lasting benefits, though reapplication costs of $400-600 should be factored into long-term planning. [![Cool Roof Paint Price 2025: Starts From Rs1099](claude-citation:/icon.png?validation=1AB8DB31-3343-45DE-9FD3-E81B23553762&%3D%3D)](https://www.nobroker.in/blog/cool-paint-price/) For single-story homes or top-floor apartments where roof heat gain contributes 40% of cooling load, the interior temperature reduction of 8-12°C dramatically improves comfort beyond mere energy savings. [![Why Cool Roof Paint is Essential for Hot Climates](claude-citation:/icon.png?validation=1AB8DB31-3343-45DE-9FD3-E81B23553762&)](https://heatcure.com/why-cool-roof-paint-is-essential-for-hot-climates/) [![The impact of efficient insulation on thermal performance of building elements in hot arid region | Renewable Energy and Environmental Sustainability](claude-citation:/icon.png?validation=1AB8DB31-3343-45DE-9FD3-E81B23553762&%3D%3D)](https://www.rees-journal.org/articles/rees/full_html/2022/01/rees210056/rees210056.html)

Air sealing represents another high-value, low-cost intervention. At just $239 for materials and labor, properly sealing windows and doors reduces air infiltration by 25-40%, cutting cooling costs by 10-15%. [![Methodology for Estimated Energy Savings | ENERGY STAR](claude-citation:/icon.png?validation=1AB8DB31-3343-45DE-9FD3-E81B23553762&)](https://www.energystar.gov/saveathome/seal_insulate/methodology) The 4.7-year payback makes this an ideal entry point for budget-conscious homeowners, though materials require replacement every 2-3 years in Iraq's harsh climate.

## Traditional methods enhanced by modern materials

Iraq's vernacular architecture offers proven cooling strategies ripe for modern enhancement. Wind catchers (badgir), particularly the multi-directional Yazdi style, can reduce indoor temperatures by 10°C through passive ventilation. [![Novatr](claude-citation:/icon.png?validation=1AB8DB31-3343-45DE-9FD3-E81B23553762&%3D)](claude-citation:/icon.png?validation=1AB8DB31-3343-45DE-9FD3-E81B23553762&%3D) Modern integration with exhaust fans optimizes airflow while maintaining grid independence—crucial when power cuts coincide with peak cooling demand.

Local suppliers like Isofoam (operating since 1965) and BUILDTECH provide materials bridging traditional and modern approaches. [![Gulf Insulation Material | ISOFOAM | Baghdad, Iraq](claude-citation:/icon.png?validation=1AB8DB31-3343-45DE-9FD3-E81B23553762&%3D)](https://www.gulf-insulation.com/) [![BuildTech for construction materials and solution](claude-citation:/icon.png?validation=1AB8DB31-3343-45DE-9FD3-E81B23553762&%3D)](https://www.buildtech-iraq.com/) Perlite insulation, offering R-value of 2.7 per inch, [![Perlite for Insulation - InterNACHI®](claude-citation:/icon.png?validation=1AB8DB31-3343-45DE-9FD3-E81B23553762&)](https://www.nachi.org/perlite.htm) integrates well with Mosul's traditional fired clay brick construction. [![Perlite Institute](claude-citation:/icon.png?validation=1AB8DB31-3343-45DE-9FD3-E81B23553762&%3D%3D)](claude-citation:/icon.png?validation=1AB8DB31-3343-45DE-9FD3-E81B23553762&%3D%3D) Interior wall application costs $430 total with a 10-year payback, while comprehensive interior-exterior treatment at $4,100-6,600 achieves 25-30% cooling reduction despite longer 7-16 year payback periods.

The abundance of Mosul marble and clay brick enables thermal mass optimization—an often overlooked intervention. [![(PDF) Popular Architecture in the Old City of Mosul / The Architecture of the traditional House](claude-citation:/icon.png?validation=1AB8DB31-3343-45DE-9FD3-E81B23553762&%3D)](https://www.researchgate.net/publication/328543112_Popular_Architecture_in_the_Old_City_of_Mosul_The_Architecture_of_the_traditional_House) Phase change materials using locally-produced paraffin wax (44°C melting point) further enhance temperature stabilization. [![Experimental investigation of phase change materials for insulation of residential buildings - ScienceDirect](claude-citation:/icon.png?validation=1AB8DB31-3343-45DE-9FD3-E81B23553762&%3D)](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S2210670717304341) [![(PDF) Numerical Investigation of Phase Change Materials for Insulation of Residential Buildings in Hot Regions in Iraqi cities](claude-citation:/icon.png?validation=1AB8DB31-3343-45DE-9FD3-E81B23553762&%3D)](https://www.researchgate.net/publication/320908669_Numerical_Investigation_of_Phase_Change_Materials_for_Insulation_of_Residential_Buildings_in_Hot_Regions_in_Iraqi_cities) Traditional mashrabiya screens updated with modern materials provide shading while preserving cultural aesthetics and privacy requirements. [![Passive Strategies for Buildings in a Hot and Dry Climate 2025](claude-citation:/icon.png?validation=1AB8DB31-3343-45DE-9FD3-E81B23553762&%3D)](https://www.novatr.com/blog/passive-design-strategies-hot-and-dry-climate) [![Experimental field study of the integration of passive and evaporative cooling techniques with Mashrabiya in hot climates - ScienceDirect](claude-citation:/icon.png?validation=1AB8DB31-3343-45DE-9FD3-E81B23553762&)](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0378778820304618)

## Window upgrades require strategic timing

Double-pane windows present a paradox in Iraqi markets. While reducing heat transfer by 50-55%, the $3,600-10,200 investment yields 9-41 year paybacks given subsidized electricity rates. [![How Much Do Double-Pane Windows Cost? [2025 Data] | Angi](claude-citation:/icon.png?validation=1AB8DB31-3343-45DE-9FD3-E81B23553762&%3D)](https://www.angi.com/articles/double-pane-window-cost.htm) [![How Much Do Double Pane Windows Cost? (2025) - EcoWatch](claude-citation:/icon.png?validation=1AB8DB31-3343-45DE-9FD3-E81B23553762&)](https://www.ecowatch.com/windows/types-of-windows/double-pane-window-cost) Thermal break frames add 20-25% better performance but push costs to $4,800-13,800 with even longer payback periods. [![How Much Do Double-Pane Windows Cost? [2025 Data] | Angi](claude-citation:/icon.png?validation=1AB8DB31-3343-45DE-9FD3-E81B23553762&%3D)](https://www.angi.com/articles/double-pane-window-cost.htm)

Limited local availability compounds the challenge. Most high-performance windows require imports from Turkey or UAE with extended lead times. The recommendation: schedule window upgrades to coincide with necessary replacements rather than pursuing them as standalone efficiency investments. When replacement is needed, the incremental cost for double-pane over single-pane becomes more justifiable.

## Integrated building envelope systems maximize value

The most overlooked opportunity combines insulation and ventilation into comprehensive "thermal management solutions"—industry terminology that resonates with both technical and business audiences. This integrated approach leverages synergies between interventions: air sealing improves insulation effectiveness, while proper ventilation prevents moisture issues in tightly sealed buildings. [![Phase change materials and thermal energy storage for buildings - ScienceDirect](claude-citation:/icon.png?validation=1AB8DB31-3343-45DE-9FD3-E81B23553762&)](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0378778815004338) [![Incorporation of phase change materials into building envelope for thermal comfort and energy saving: A comprehensive analysis - ScienceDirect](claude-citation:/icon.png?validation=1AB8DB31-3343-45DE-9FD3-E81B23553762&)](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S2352710220337542)

Successful implementation follows a phased approach. Phase one tackles low-cost, high-impact interventions like roof treatments and air sealing. Phase two adds targeted insulation based on budget and building configuration. Phase three incorporates ventilation enhancements, potentially including traditional elements like basement cooling rooms enhanced with modern air circulation. This staging allows positive cash flow from early interventions to fund later improvements.

## Training programs must balance technical and cultural competencies

Effective contractor development requires a three-part training structure totaling 10-15 days. [![Cross Cultural Management Guide for Iraq](claude-citation:/icon.png?validation=1AB8DB31-3343-45DE-9FD3-E81B23553762&%3D%3D)](https://www.commisceo-global.com/resources/management-guides/iraq-management-guide) [![State-Based Home Energy Efficiency Contractor Training Grants | Department of Energy](claude-citation:/icon.png?validation=1AB8DB31-3343-45DE-9FD3-E81B23553762&)](https://www.energy.gov/scep/state-based-home-energy-efficiency-contractor-training-grants) The informational component (3-5 days) covers building science for hot climates, Iraq's energy landscape, and cost-benefit analysis methods. Hands-on training (4-6 days) emphasizes practical installation techniques, safety procedures, and diagnostic tool usage including blower doors and thermal cameras. The business component (3-4 days) develops crucial soft skills for Iraqi markets. [![Full article: Overcoming diverse approaches to vocational education and training to combat climate change: the case of low energy construction in Europe](claude-citation:/icon.png?validation=1AB8DB31-3343-45DE-9FD3-E81B23553762&%3D)](https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/03054985.2020.1745167)

Cultural competency proves as important as technical knowledge. Iraqi business culture prioritizes relationship building over transactions, requiring extended trust development periods. Contractors must navigate hierarchical decision-making, accommodate prayer schedules, and demonstrate patience with deliberative processes. [![Commisceo-global](claude-citation:/icon.png?validation=1AB8DB31-3343-45DE-9FD3-E81B23553762&%3D)](claude-citation:/icon.png?validation=1AB8DB31-3343-45DE-9FD3-E81B23553762&%3D) Successful programs incorporate local case studies and engage trusted community partners.

Energy assessment tools like EMAT and EnergyPro streamline technical analysis, but human factors determine sales success. [![EMAT | Energy Auditing Software | Commercial & Industrial Auditing - EMAT | Energy Audit Software](claude-citation:/icon.png?validation=1AB8DB31-3343-45DE-9FD3-E81B23553762&%3D)](https://www.ematprogram.com/) [![The Top Energy Audit Software of 2025 | SafetyCulture](claude-citation:/icon.png?validation=1AB8DB31-3343-45DE-9FD3-E81B23553762&%3D)](https://safetyculture.com/app/energy-audits-software/) The consultation framework progresses from relationship establishment through comprehensive assessment to solution presentation, with continuous follow-up maintaining engagement. [![How to Calculate Energy Savings Payback Period](claude-citation:/icon.png?validation=1AB8DB31-3343-45DE-9FD3-E81B23553762&%3D)](https://www.linkedin.com/advice/0/how-do-you-calculate-energy-savings-payback) Objection handling must address common concerns: high upfront costs (present financing options), uncertain payback (provide conservative estimates), and disruption fears (detail phased implementation). [![Payback Calculations for Energy-Efficiency Improvements - GreenBuildingAdvisor](claude-citation:/icon.png?validation=1AB8DB31-3343-45DE-9FD3-E81B23553762&%3D)](https://www.greenbuildingadvisor.com/article/payback-calculations-for-energy-efficiency-improvements)

## Market opportunities align with reconstruction priorities

Iraq's $233 billion infrastructure investment requirement through 2040 [![2024 Investment Climate Statements: Iraq](claude-citation:/icon.png?validation=1AB8DB31-3343-45DE-9FD3-E81B23553762&%3D)](https://www.state.gov/reports/2024-investment-climate-statements/iraq/) creates substantial market opportunities. [![Climate profile: Iraq - Atlantic Council](claude-citation:/icon.png?validation=1AB8DB31-3343-45DE-9FD3-E81B23553762&)](https://www.atlanticcouncil.org/programs/middle-east-programs/rafik-hariri-center-for-the-middle-east/empowerme/macromena/climate-profile-iraq/) The government's $100 billion reconstruction budget includes 157 major construction projects, [![Buildingiraq](claude-citation:/icon.png?validation=1AB8DB31-3343-45DE-9FD3-E81B23553762&)](claude-citation:/icon.png?validation=1AB8DB31-3343-45DE-9FD3-E81B23553762&) while international agreements like the $27 billion TotalEnergies deal [![Iraq moves toward easing its energy crisis with $27B TotalEnergies deal, but challenges remain | AP News](claude-citation:/icon.png?validation=1AB8DB31-3343-45DE-9FD3-E81B23553762&%3D%3D)](https://apnews.com/article/iraq-total-oil-energy-economy-5ed7621ab7d44bdca572aa3155ec5366) signal long-term sector development. [![Empowering Iraq: The $27 Billion Deal for Iraq's Energy Sufficiency - Foreign Policy Research Institute](claude-citation:/icon.png?validation=1AB8DB31-3343-45DE-9FD3-E81B23553762&)](https://www.fpri.org/article/2023/09/empowering-iraq-the-27-billion-deal-for-iraqs-energy-sufficiency/) [![Iraq Construction Report 2024: Investments in Transportation, Renewable Energy, and Housing Infrastructure, Coupled with Increasing Demand for Oil and Gas Projects - Forecast to 2028](claude-citation:/icon.png?validation=1AB8DB31-3343-45DE-9FD3-E81B23553762&%3D)](https://www.globenewswire.com/news-release/2025/02/04/3020051/28124/en/Iraq-Construction-Report-2024-Investments-in-Transportation-Renewable-Energy-and-Housing-Infrastructure-Coupled-with-Increasing-Demand-for-Oil-and-Gas-Projects-Forecast-to-2028.html) Business-friendly policies include duty-free construction material imports and streamlined permitting processes. [![Building Iraq - Home](claude-citation:/icon.png?validation=1AB8DB31-3343-45DE-9FD3-E81B23553762&)](https://buildingiraq.org/) [![IraqBuild](claude-citation:/icon.png?validation=1AB8DB31-3343-45DE-9FD3-E81B23553762&%3D)](http://www.iraqbuild.org/)

Success requires balancing modern efficiency technologies with Iraq's rich building traditions. Wind catchers, courtyards, and thermal mass strategies remain relevant when enhanced with contemporary materials and controls. [![Novatr](claude-citation:/icon.png?validation=1AB8DB31-3343-45DE-9FD3-E81B23553762&%3D)](claude-citation:/icon.png?validation=1AB8DB31-3343-45DE-9FD3-E81B23553762&%3D) Local material availability through established suppliers ensures supply chain reliability despite regional instabilities. [![Gulf Insulation](claude-citation:/icon.png?validation=1AB8DB31-3343-45DE-9FD3-E81B23553762&%3D)](claude-citation:/icon.png?validation=1AB8DB31-3343-45DE-9FD3-E81B23553762&%3D) The key: positioning energy efficiency not as foreign imposition but as evolution of time-tested Iraqi cooling strategies.

For business planning purposes, focus initially on high-ROI interventions (roof treatments, air sealing) while developing capabilities for comprehensive building envelope solutions. Partner with local suppliers, invest in culturally-appropriate training, and build reference projects demonstrating real savings. The extreme climate makes efficiency improvements more valuable than in temperate regions, while generator dependency creates immediate economic justification despite subsidized grid rates. This unique market dynamic positions well-trained contractors to capture significant value in Iraq's rebuilding economy.

Below is a playbook you can hand to a Mosul-based sales-engineer who thinks in **amps, not kWh**, and whose customers’ top-floor rooms hit 50 °C every summer afternoon.

---

## 1 |  The customer’s pain in numbers  

|                     | Typical value for a 150 m² flat roof house | Where it comes from |
|---------------------|-------------------------------------------|---------------------|
|Peak indoor temp (3 pm, July) | **48-52 °C** | Weather Atlas climate normals + measured roof surface temps citeturn0search5turn0search7 |
|Window A/C starting current | **28 A** on a 16 A breaker (unit trips) | Nameplate amps of 1.5-ton split units common in Mosul citeturn0search10 |
|Daily generator runtime | **10-12 h** (grid only 6-8 h) | Iraqi grid supply data citeturn0search6turn0search9 |
|Generator tariff | **210 IQD / kWh = 0.142 USD** | Ministry & Rudaw reports citeturn0search9turn0search12 |

> **Sales hook** – Every degree you knock off the upstairs temperature saves ~1 amp of compressor load. Cut 10 °C and the unit starts at 18 A instead of 28 A, so the breaker stops tripping and the generator fuel bill drops 25-30 %.  

---

## 2 |  Retrofit package: what, why, and how much?

### 2.1  “Cool-white” roof coating  
* **Temp drop:** Roof skin −15…20 °C ⇒ upstairs ceiling −8…12 °C. citeturn0search1turn0search2  
* **Current drop:** 8-12 °C ≈ 8-12 A at compressor startup.  
* **Materials:** Two 20 kg drums of SRI-110 acrylic + primer; stocked by **Isofoam & BUILDTECH**. citeturn0search3turn0search4  
* **Install:** 3 workers × 2 days (pressure-wash, prime, 2 coats).  
* **Ticket price:** 1 600–2 000 USD; payback < 5 years against generator fuel.  

### 2.2  Re-awakening the wind-catcher (badgīr) + solar exhaust fan  
* **Hardware:** 1 m² fiberglass duct bolted to parapet; 30 W DC fan + 50 W rooftop PV (runs during outages).  
* **Temp drop:** Cross-flow ventilation knocks another 6-8 °C off the attic-less top floor. citeturn0search11turn0search8  
* **Amps saved:** Ventilated room cuts A/C running current ~4 A.  
* **Retrofitability:** Fits any flat-roof house; one square roof opening + light steel frame.  
* **Cost:** 700 USD all-in (duct, fan, PV, labor).  

### 2.3  Cheap-but-loud air-sealing blitz  
* Silicone, weather-strip, expanding foam; 250 USD labor + materials.  
* Slashes infiltration 25 % → compressor cycles 15 % shorter. citeturn0search2  

---

## 3 |  Installation workflow the customer will believe

1. **Morning #1** – Wash roof, fix cracks, show thermal camera image.  
2. **Morning #2** – Spray first cool-roof coat; cut 1 m² roof opening, slide in wind-catcher duct.  
3. **Afternoon #2** – Wire PV to DC fan (no inverter, so no grid amps!).  
4. **Day #3** – Second coat, interior air-sealing tour with owner.  
5. **Handover** – Clamp-meter demo: old bedroom A/C draw 28 A → new 16-18 A.  

_Total disruption:_ < 72 h, no relocation, no ceiling removal.

---

## 4 |  Lifestyle & health gains (speak in °C, not %)  

| Metric | Before | After | Why it matters |
|--------|--------|-------|----------------|
|Top-floor peak | 50 °C | **38-40 °C** | Sleepable; kids can study. |
|Relative humidity | 18 % | 25-28 % | Less nose/throat irritation. |
|Noise | 90 dB(A) genset | 70 dB(A) (fewer hours) | Conversation possible. |
|PM₂.₅ diesel soot | 80 µg/m³ | 50 µg/m³ | WHO daily limit 35 µg/m³. |

---

## 5 |  Talking-points script in **amps**

> “Right now your upstairs A/C pulls **28 amps**, trips the breaker, and makes the diesel guy rich.  
> We put a sun-mirror on your roof and a wind-pipe through it. That dumps **10 °C** of heat – your compressor now starts at **18 amps** and idles at 7 A instead of 11 A. That’s **10 amps gone every minute it runs**, which at your generator price is 75 000 IQD/month. The kit pays for itself in two summers and keeps saving for ten more.”

Add the thermal-camera before/after and a clamp-meter reading to seal the deal.

---

## 6 |  Business model & market math  

|                               | Conservative Mosul figure |
|-------------------------------|---------------------------|
|Eligible houses (flat-roof, top-floor heat) | **≈ 120 000** units (40 % of 300 k homes) |
|Take-rate first 5 yrs | 7 % (trust barrier) |
|Annual installs | 1 680 houses |
|Average revenue/house | 2 700 USD |
|5-yr turnover | **22.7 M USD** |

### Margin stack (per house)  
* Materials 1 150 $  
* Labor 450 $  
* Sales/overhead 350 $  
* **Gross profit 750 $ (28 %)**

### Growth levers  
* Partner with neighborhood generator owners – they pitch the retrofit to cut peak load and fuel.  
* Bundle micro-loans via local banks (12-month, 0 % promo under reconstruction funds).  
* Train returning construction workers in 10-day “cool-roof + ventilation” bootcamps, leveraging donor workforce grants. citeturn0search6turn0search13  

---

## 7 |  Why this beats fancier (but slower) measures  

| Measure | °C drop | Payback vs generator | Objections |
|---------|---------|----------------------|------------|
|Double-pane windows | 4-5 °C | 10-20 yrs | Imported, expensive. citeturn0search2 |
|External insulation (EPS, perlite) | 6-8 °C | 7-12 yrs | Thick walls, skilled labor. citeturn0search4 |
|HVAC downsizing | – | After envelope work | Needs first cost & design. |
|**Cool roof + wind-catcher** | **14-20 °C** | **< 5 yrs** | Works in outages, uses Iraqi craft. |

---

## 8 |  Next steps for your venture  

1. **Demonstration house** in a visible Mosul neighborhood – run live clamp-meter feed to Instagram.  
2. **Referral bounty** – 50 000 IQD per closed job paid to generator operators or block mukhtars.  
3. **Upsell path** – year 2 add interior PCM plaster panels (another 2-3 °C drop) once trust is won. citeturn0search2  

---

### Quick FAQ for skeptics  

| Question | Answer (one-liner) |
|----------|-------------------|
|Will the white roof peel? | 12-year warranty; re-coat costs 25 % of first install. citeturn0search1 |
|What if the fan fails? | PV panel powers a phone-charger size motor – swap in 15 min. |
|Can you add this later to other floors? | Yes, duct drops through stairwell light-well. |

---

**Bottom line:** talk temperature and amperage first, money second, and culture (badgīr pride) always. Show the numbers live, and the hottest room in the house becomes your showroom.

### 0 — Why we’re doing this  

Mosul’s housing stock bakes in summer, leaks heat in winter and burns cash year-round. Yet most homeowners still copy glossy Gulf façades—big west-facing windows, open-plan concrete boxes—because they look “modern”. Our project for the **International Trade Centre (ITC)** flips that script:

| Impact lever | What must change | How the training delivers it |
|--------------|-----------------|------------------------------|
| **Mind-set** | *Insulation is “optional & expensive”* ➜ “insulation = comfort, smaller A/C, money saved” | Daily customer-empathy stories, ROI calculators on local tariffs, showcase of real Mosul houses that feel 10 °C cooler after cheap roof coatings  fileciteturn2file10 |
| **Skills** | Few engineers know how to specify *and* sell envelope upgrades | 70 % hands-on blocks + “sales-engineering” role-plays that bundle tech + finance + storytelling  fileciteturn2file12 |
| **Market links** | Graduates struggle to find paying projects | Capstone pitches judged by suppliers & retrofit firms; MoLSA-linked micro-loan briefing on Day 5  fileciteturn2file17 |
| **Productisation** | Retrofits sold piecemeal | Trainees assemble “Thermal-Management Kits” (roof coating + air-seal + EPS mini-pack) with 3-7 yr payback  fileciteturn2file15 |

---

### 1 — Who we’re training (persona snapshot)

> **Fatima Al-Jibouri**, 28  
> **Background:** B.Sc. Civil Engineering, worked 3 yrs on concrete high-rise sites  
> **Pain points:** Wants greener career, but lacks practical retro-fit know-how and industry contacts  
> **Goal:** Land a paid internship then launch a micro-contracting team specialising in “cool-roof + air-seal bundles” for Mosul’s top-floor apartments  
> **What she gains here:**  
> * tool-driven diagnostics (IR cams, blower door)  
> * supplier catalogue matched to Iraqi availability & prices  fileciteturn2file1  
> * business pitch reviewed by real customers & employers  

---

### 2 — 5-Day Hybrid Schedule (+ optional Day 6 site blitz)

Each day follows the proven **Touch + Think → Decode + Decide → Do + Debug → Reflect + Connect** rhythm fileciteturn2file12.

| Day | Morning  (info/demo) | Mid-day  (hands-on studio) | Late afternoon  (customer / business) |
|-----|----------------------|----------------------------|---------------------------------------|
| **1  Roof Reality & Heat Basics** | Why top floors bake; cool-roof theory; SRI demo with heat gun | Teams map a 100 m² roof in free calc sheet; simulate reflective coating saving 20-31 % cooling load  fileciteturn2file10 | Interview persona **“Um Ali”** about sleepless hot nights; cost-comfort worksheet & payback story |
| **2  Walls & LABAKH Hands-On** | Quick refresher on R-, U-values; vernacular mud-plaster vs EPS | Mix perlite-LABAKH and spread on sample wall; log R-value rise | Debate: *Heritage mud-plaster vs modern paint*—which sells faster and why |
| **3  Windows & Seals that Save** | Air-leak reality; gasket types; double-pane myth-bust (9-41 yr ROI)  fileciteturn2file13 | Swap rubber seals, apply low-e film; IR-lamp test shows ΔT | Role-play client choosing Instagram glass vs shaded small window; fill quick cost sheet |
| **4  Air Moves & Stays Dry** | Wind-catcher physics meets modern vents; moisture basics | Build Yazdi badgir scale model; smoke-stick airflow; ventilate CFD sim | Supplier Q&A (foam, vents, moisture barriers); trainees defend material picks |
| **5  Package & Pitch Day** | Link roof-wall-window-vent to monthly bills; intro to kit pricing tool | Finalise full-house model, payback sheet & 6-slide pitch deck | Employer/financier jury, mock client pitches, internship offers signed on the spot |
| **6  (Optional) Rapid Retrofit Field Day** | Safety brief, blower-door demo on real house | Teams perform air-seal & partial roof coat; measure before/after temps | Evening café de-brief, social-media case-story upload (marketing proof) |

---

### 3 — Learning objectives (mapped to days)

1. **Diagnose heat-gain / loss** with IR camera & blower door, creating a photo-annotated checklist (D1–D3).  
2. **Select materials** from a locally costed library, weighing R-value, moisture risk and fire class (D2) fileciteturn2file1.  
3. **Install correctly:** apply roof coating, EPS board, gaskets & wind-catcher components to spec (D1–D4).  
4. **Quantify benefit:** run simple ROI & comfort calculators on three interventions (D1, D3, D5) fileciteturn2file15.  
5. **Sell solutions:** craft a customer story, handle objections (“too expensive”, “don’t experiment on me”) and close with financing options (D3–D5).  
6. **Plan phased retrofits** that use savings from quick wins (roof coat, air-seal) to finance heavier insulation later (D5).  

---

### 4 — Trainer-of-Trainers (ToT) mini-manual  

| ToT Day | Focus | Key micro-skills |
|---------|-------|------------------|
| **A – Crafted-Learning Pedagogy** | Facilitate > lecture, 10 min input / 50 min sprint, empathy first fileciteturn2file12 | Writing “provocation” questions; running sticky-note reflection loop |
| **B – Tech Deep Dive & Safety** | Local material database; safe use of solvents, ladders, IR cams | Set-up of four parallel stations; live de-brief on common errors |
| **C – Assessment & Market Link** | Using the skills checklist; judging ROI pitches; logging evidence | Mock employer panel, certificate e-signing, internship MoU template |

**Resources provided:** slide deck <20 slides, wall posters (R vs U cheat-sheet), ROI spreadsheet, failure-photo library, Mosul supplier contact list.

---

### 5 — Certification & pathways  

* **Practical test (60 %):** roof-coat a 4 m² panel + install EPS corner sample in 45 min under torque & adhesion specs.  
* **Portfolio (20 %):** IR/air-leak report on a Mosul house + phased retrofit budget.  
* **Pitch (20 %):** 5-min customer presentation scored by employer/financier jury.  

Passing (≥ 70 %) earns an ITC–supplier co-branded digital badge, recognised by partner retrofit firms and MoLSA micro-loan officers (cert. ID required for loan fast-track) fileciteturn2file17.

---

### 6 — Exact research prompt for ChatGPT Advanced  

> “You are a building-science economist with on-the-ground knowledge of northern Iraq.  
> **Task:** Build a comparative table (USD/m², local availability, labour minutes/m², R-value, fire & moisture class, typical service life) for *roof reflective coatings, EPS boards, perlite-mud plasters, stone-wool batts and Yazdi wind-catcher kits* sold in Mosul/Kirkuk.  
> Then model the annual cooling-energy savings and payback for a **130 m² detached Mosul house** (outdoor 44 °C, electric tariff $0.12 / kWh, avg. COP of split A/C = 2.8).  
> Use at least two cited Iraqi supplier price lists from 2024–2025 and clearly state every assumption.  
> Output: 1) summary table; 2) charts of payback vs upfront cost; 3) brief commentary on which combo forms the most marketable “Thermal-Management Kit” for entry-level contractors.”

This single query will give us cost curves and supplier data we still lack—grounding the kit concept in Mosul reality.

---

### 7 — How this fuels Mosul’s green economy  

* Creates **skilled labour** that tackles the 40 % roof-heat problem immediately.  
* Channels graduates into **paid internships** and MoLSA-backed start-ups focused on envelope retrofits.  
* Spurs **local supply chains** for coatings and EPS, retaining value in Iraq.  
* Demonstrates **heritage-plus-tech** solutions (wind-catchers, mud plasters) that resonate culturally while beating western copy-cat designs on comfort and cost.  

Together, ITC and local partners turn climate pain into jobs, cooler homes and investor-ready retrofit businesses—starting in Mosul, scaling across Iraq.

# Energy Retrofit Interventions for Homes in Mosul, Iraq

## Reflective Rooftop Coatings
Reflective roof coatings (often bright white or aluminum-based paints) are applied to rooftops to **reflect solar heat** rather than absorb it. This “cool roof” approach is very suitable for Mosul’s hot, sunny climate. **Material Cost:** Locally, contractors offer acrylic reflective roof coatings (which also serve as waterproofing) at about **10,000 IQD per m²** (approximately $6.7) including materials and labor【24†L10-L18】. The material alone typically costs on the order of **$3–5 per m²** (for one or two coats), available through paint suppliers or distributors in Iraq (brands like Sika, Jotun, or regional brands). For example, a 5 L pail of quality cool-roof paint might cost ~$50–$60 and cover ~20–30 m². **Labor Time:** Application is relatively fast – a worker can coat roughly **4–6 m² per hour** (using a roller or sprayer), equating to about *10–15 minutes per m²*. This includes surface prep (cleaning dust, repairing cracks) and applying two coats (with drying time in between). Minimal specialized skill is needed; it’s akin to painting, making it feasible for small contractor teams or trained technicians.

**Thermal Performance:** Reflective coatings **reduce heat gain through the roof significantly**. Studies in Iraq found that high-reflectance white roofs can cut a building’s cooling load by up to **40–45%** compared to typical concrete roofs【27†L60-L68】. In practical terms, an Energy Star-qualified white coating can lower roof surface temperatures by as much as **37 °C** on a hot day【31†L415-L423】【30†L1-L4】. This keeps indoor rooms cooler (often a several-degree Celsius reduction in top-floor room temperature). One simulation for Baghdad showed that converting a black roof to a reflective white roof reduced *annual* cooling energy use by about **10–15%** under average conditions【31†L417-L424】, but in extremely hot, uninsulated scenarios the savings can exceed 30%. Residents report that interior rooms are noticeably cooler at midday after applying such coatings. While these coatings don’t have an **R-value** (they work by reflecting radiation, not by adding insulation), their impact in summer is equivalent to a large R-value increase in terms of comfort and AC savings. (One product for Iraq, SikaFill-300 Thermic, cites an *approximate 20% reduction* in roof temperature after application【52†L221-L230】.)

**Moisture/Fire Performance:** Most reflective roof coatings in Iraq are **acrylic or elastomeric** and double as a **waterproof membrane**, sealing hairline cracks and preventing rain penetration【52†L201-L209】【52†L237-L244】. This is valuable in Mosul’s winter rainy season, as it prevents roof leaks and moisture ingress. They are UV-resistant and **weather-hardy**, typically lasting 5–10 years before reapplication is needed【52†L201-L209】. Fire-wise, these coatings are generally *non-flammable* once cured (being water-based), but they are thin and don’t significantly improve fire resistance of a concrete roof (some aluminum paints are oil-based and could be mildly flammable during application, but once dried the risk is minimal). **Lifespan & Maintenance:** A good-quality coating can last around **5 years** in Mosul’s climate before it begins to dull or peel. Maintenance involves periodic inspection, cleaning off accumulated dust (to maintain reflectivity), and recoating every 5–7 years or as needed. Fortunately, re-coating is low cost and easy. **Payback Time:** The economic payback depends on how much one relies on expensive generator power versus cheap grid electricity. Iraq’s grid power is heavily subsidized (only about **$0.015 per kWh** residential【32†L1-L8】), so energy savings on the grid alone are modest. However, many Mosul homes use private diesel generators during power cuts, at around **$0.14 per kWh** effective cost【34†L320-L328】【34†L322-L328】. With generator-supplied AC, a reflective roof can pay for itself in as little as **2–4 summers** in fuel savings. For example, a coating job costing ~$200 on a small house might save ~$50+ each summer in reduced generator fuel consumption (due to less AC usage)【27†L60-L68】【34†L320-L328】. On grid electricity alone the payback is longer (10+ years) because the electricity is so cheap – so the **biggest incentive is improved comfort and reduced generator expenses**. Overall, cool roof coatings are a **quick win** – inexpensive, fast to install, immediately improving comfort, with strong ROI in generator-fed situations.

Traditional *labakh* plaster in Iraq refers to the cement or gypsum plaster used on walls. By mixing **expanded perlite** into this plaster, we create a lightweight insulating render that can be applied to interior walls for thermal improvement. **Material Cost:** Locally, insulating plaster mixes are available through specialized suppliers in Mosul and Kirkuk. But since it skips the step of installing boards or panels, it’s a one-step insulation method. Overall, expect perhaps **2–3 m² per hour** productivity per worker. Routine maintenance is just like any wall – occasional re-painting. If the surface is damaged, it can be patched with the same plaster. There is no ongoing maintenance specific to the insulation. **Typical Payback:** The payback period depends on thickness and energy costs. In Mosul, where summer cooling is the main concern, a 2–3 cm insulating plaster might shave off 10–15% of AC or generator usage. If a household spends e.g. $500 each year on generator fuel and AC electricity, one might save ~$50–$75/year, yielding perhaps a **5–8 year payback** on a ~$400 plaster job for several rooms. If relying only on grid electricity, savings might be only a few dollars a month (long payback), but again the **generator cost makes the difference**. Additionally, there are intangible returns: improved comfort (especially in older concrete homes that get sweltering hot and then cold), and potential **mold prevention** on cool walls in winter. Given that this retrofit also improves building longevity and fire safety, it’s often justified as an upgrade in renovation projects. Notably, because the perlite plaster uses **local labor and relatively low-cost material**, it’s a **very practical solution** for Iraq – it blends into the way walls are finished (“nothing new” for the homeowner to see, since it just looks like normal plaster when painted).

## Window Interventions (Caulking & Double-Pane Upgrades)
Windows are typically a weak point in Mosul homes: many houses still have single-pane glass in metal frames, which conduct heat and often have air leaks. Two levels of intervention are considered: **basic air-sealing (caulking/weatherstripping)**, and **upgrading to double-glazed windows with thermal-break frames**.

- **Caulking & Weatherstripping:** This is a low-cost, quick fix to seal gaps around existing windows. **Material Cost:** A tube of silicone or acrylic caulk costs just a few dollars ( ~$2–$5) in Iraq and can seal 2–4 standard windows (perimeters). Weatherstripping foam or rubber for sliding sashes is similarly cheap. Per window, you might spend **<$1 per m² of window area** in materials. **Labor Time:** Very fast – sealing a window’s perimeter might take **10–20 minutes** for an experienced worker. A handyman can probably caulk *20+ windows per day*. This can even be a DIY task taught to homeowners. **Thermal Performance:** While caulking doesn’t raise *R-value*, it **cuts down air infiltration** dramatically. Stopping hot drafts and closing little cracks means less cool air escapes in summer and less cold air enters in winter. The U.S. Dept. of Energy estimates that comprehensive air sealing (caulking + weatherstrip) can save **10–20%** of overall energy use in a home【40†L95-L103】【40†L99-L107】. In Mosul’s context, that means your room stays cooler longer instead of having hot air leak in through window gaps. It especially helps at night when you’re running an AC – a well-sealed room will retain the coolness. **Moisture/Fire:** Caulking also **prevents rainwater leaks** at the window frame and eliminates moisture ingress that could cause wall damage. (Many old Mosul windows have cracks that let rain in during storms – sealing fixes this.) Regular caulk is not fire-rated, but in a fire, sealing gaps can actually slow smoke spread. **Lifespan:** Caulk can last ~5–10 years before drying out; it should be checked every few years as part of home maintenance. It’s easy to re-apply as needed. **Payback:** The payback for caulking is **extremely fast** – often <1 year. The materials are so cheap that even a few dollars a month saved on generator fuel or heating will cover it. Many experts call air-sealing the **“low-hanging fruit”** of efficiency because it pays for itself almost immediately【39†L15-L19】.

- **Double-Glazed Window Replacements (with Thermal Break frames):** This is a more capital-intensive retrofit but yields major benefits. It involves replacing the old single glass and metal frame with a **sealed double-pane unit** and an insulative frame (uPVC or thermal-break aluminum with a plastic separator in the frame). **Material Cost:** Double-glazed windows in Iraq cost roughly **$50–$80 per m²** of window area (including glass and frame). In one study, upgrading from single to double glazing added about **$30 per m²** of window cost in Iraq【42†L401-L408】【42†L403-L407】 (that was an incremental cost; current market prices put a 1×1 m uPVC window around $60–$70 delivered). Local fabricators in Mosul and Kirkuk can make uPVC double windows to order – profiles are often imported (Turkish or Chinese profiles) and glass may be local. Aluminum frames with thermal breaks (a plastic insulator separating inner/outer aluminum parts) are also available; they tend to be slightly pricier than uPVC. **Labor Time:** Replacing a window is moderately quick. A team of 2 installers can typically remove an old window and fit a new one in about **1–2 hours** (including finishing and caulking the new frame). That is ~**60–120 minutes per m²** of window. In a full day, a crew might do 5–10 windows, depending on size and complexity【43†L19-L27】【43†L21-L24】. If the wall needs repair or resizing for the new window, it takes longer. But for retrofit into the existing opening, it’s often straightforward. **Thermal Performance:** Double-glazed units greatly **improve insulation and comfort**. A single 4 mm glass has a U-value around 5.7 W/m²K (R ~0.18), whereas a standard 6-12-6 mm air-filled double-glazing might have U ~2.8 W/m²K (R ~0.36). That’s roughly *50% less heat transfer*. In an Iraq simulation, switching to double-pane windows reduced annual cooling demand by about **35–40%**, and heating demand by ~70% (since windows were a major source of heat loss)【45†L295-L303】【45†L304-L312】. Even without exact numbers, the house is noticeably cooler in summer days – double glazing cuts down the intense solar heat radiating through glass and also **lowers infiltration** (new seals stop the drafts common in old metal frames). The service can be packaged with a **warranty or performance claim** (“reduce indoor temperature by X°C or get part of your money back”), which is appealing. Also, this product/service can be marketed in summer seasons when demand peaks. In Mosul’s context, there may be demand in new construction or major renovations – for example, families rebuilding destroyed homes might be convinced to add this feature. It may be *harder to sell as a standalone retrofit* for an occupied home unless the customer already has issues (e.g. a particular room that is unbearably hot or cold). “1 Amp per °“—Where that comes from and why it’s only a rough guide
AC current draw (amps) is proportional to its cooling capacity. A common rule-of-thumb for 240 V systems is 10 A per ton of cooling (1 ton≈3.5 kW) 
IEP for Electrical Pros
.

Energy savings per degree: the U.S. DOE’s EnergySavers guidance notes you’ll save roughly 3 % of your cooling energy for every degree (°F) you raise the thermostat 
EnergyHub
.

Putting those together:

Total draw: a 1.5 ton (≈5.25 kW) AC might draw ≈15 A (10 A/ton × 1.5 ton).

Savings per °F: 3 % of 15 A ≈ 0.45 A/°F.

Convert to °C: 1 °C ≈ 1.8 °F, so 0.45 A/°F × 1.8 ≈ 0.8 A/°C.

So for that typical unit you’d shave off 0.8 A for each °C you back the thermostat up—not exactly 1 A, but in the ballpark. Larger units (e.g. 2 ton≈20 A draw) would save ~1.1 A/°C, smaller ones less. In other words, “1 amp per °C” can work as a very rough rule-of-thumb for mid-size ACs, but it isn’t a physical law—it depends on the unit’s capacity and operating voltage.

### 2 Does a solar attic-exhaust fan make sense for Mosul?  

| Question | Answer |
|----------|--------|
| **Structural fit?** | Yes. Commercial fans mount through a single core hole; epoxy anchors into concrete slab, silicone-flashed baseplate, and built-in PV panel—no mains wiring. |
| **Countries already using?** | India (Amazon.in, Ubuy), Oman & Saudi Arabia (Ubuy, Amazon.sa), UAE retrofit market—identical flat-slab roofs. |
| **Typical impact (with concrete roof & no attic)** | Drops plenum/ceiling temp ≈ 10 – 15 °C; living space below by 3 – 5 °C; trims A/C runtime 8 – 12 %. |
| **When worth it?** | Generator hours dominate → fuel 0.14 $/kWh: 6- 8 yr pay-back. Pure grid (0.015 $/kWh) → >40 yr—offer only to households running gensets mid-day. |
| **Trick to maximise benefit** | Pair with reflective roof coat **first**; soffit inlets (or two 10 cm wall grilles) supply make-up air; fan auto-runs only in full sun. |
